At that time, the Venerable MahÄmaudgalyÄyana addressed the Buddha, saying: World-Honored One! If a bodhisattva
thinks like this:
'I can expound the assembly of the Dharma.'
Such a bodhisattva will not be able to expound it.
Why is it so?
One who has the view of self gives rise to this thought:
'I can expound the Dharma, and that person listens to the Dharma.'
If a person is far removed from the notion of self, such a person does not see that I can expound the Dharma and that he can hear the Dharma, does not see those two, but is not blind to the two.
World-Honored One!
All existent dharmas are not truly existent. Any dharma that gives rise to a discriminating mind, considering it to be truly existent, should be known as a dharma that is false and not real.
The bodhisattvas do not give rise to discrimination regarding that dharma, considering it to be a truly existent dharma.
Why is it so?
It is because one does not give rise to discrimination, considering it to be truly existent.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know that all dharmas are false and unreal, like a phantom person speaking.
World-Honored One!
The false is truly non-existent but seems to exist. Such dharmas accord with emptiness, do not contradict dependent arising, and accord with non-arising and non-cessation.

This person does not contradict the dharma of emptiness and dependent arising, accords with non-arising and non-cessation, abandons various discriminations, cuts off the view of self and mine, and is far removed from all wrong views.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know that all dharmas are false, yet they are able to accord with the world and speak of existence.
If one is able to speak of false dharmas in this way to cause others to understand, this is called the Dharma-collection of the one who can speak.
What kind of dharmas are spoken of as the Dharma-collection?
Speaking of all dharmas, the dharmas are all of one characteristic. Such a Dharma-collection is called the subtle Dharma-collection.
World-Honored One!
The Dharma collection that I now expound, is it in accordance with the Dharma collection expounded by the TathÄgata?
The Buddha said:
So it is, MaudgalyÄyana!
What you have said accords with the Buddha's intention.
At that time, the Venerable PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaniputra addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
World-Honored One!
If a person expounds the Dharma collection for the sake of seeking blessings, what that person expounds will be criticized.
Why is it so?
Because of attachment to self.

If a person is attached to the characteristics of self and what belongs to self, then whatever that person does, whether it is sinful, meritorious, or immovable karma, and whatever that person does based on wrong views, one should know that such a person is unable to benefit themselves or others.
World-Honored One!
If a person is unable to understand such a Dharma collection, then that person will not give rise to sinful, meritorious, or immovable karma.

If a person is able to understand the Dharma collection, then that person will not accumulate the five aggregates, nor will they not accumulate them. They will not accumulate the twelve sense fields, nor will they not accumulate them. They will not accumulate the eighteen elements, nor will they not accumulate them. They will not accumulate the four noble truths, nor will they not accumulate them.
It neither accumulates the eighteen realms nor does it not accumulate them, and it neither accumulates the twelve sense bases nor does it not accumulate them.
This person neither grasps sentient beings nor does he not grasp them, and he neither grasps dharmas nor does he not grasp them. He
does not grasp reality nor does he grasp falsity, and he neither grasps the sense fields nor does he depart from the sense fields.

This person neither grasps greed, anger, and delusion nor does he depart from greed, anger, and delusion. He neither grasps the world norğŸ”½does he grasp nirvÄá¹‡a, and he neither grasps disputes nor does he grasp silence. He neither grasps emptiness nor does he grasp wrong views,
and he neither grasps the signless nor does he grasp discursive thought. He neither grasps the wishless
nor does he not grasp it, and he neither grasps the dharmas of buddhas nor does he grasp the dharmas of ordinary beings. He
neither grasps dharmas nor does he grasp non-dharmas, and he neither grasps the noble saá¹…gha nor does he grasp the non-Buddhist saá¹…gha.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas understand all dharmas and do not seek ultimate reality.
Why is it so?
Because this bodhisattva knows that all dharmas are ultimately real.
This bodhisattva does not seek liberation, because all dharmas are inherently quiescent and non-liberation.
This bodhisattva does not delight in a single dharma, nor does he detest a single dharma.
This bodhisattva knows that the buddhas' dharmas are neither one's own dharmas nor the dharmas of others.
He does not grasp a single dharma, nor does he abandon a single dharma. If there is grasping or abandoning, it is to be reproached;
He does not practice or abide [in the dharmas], if there is practicing or abiding, it is also to be reproached;
He is neither joyful nor sorrowful, if there is joy or sorrow, it is also to be reproached.
World-Honored One!
This is called the Dharma-collection.
World-Honored One!
Do I now speak the Dharma-collection in accordance with what the TathÄgata has said?
The Buddha said:
PÅ«rá¹‡a!
What you have said accords with the Buddha's intention.
At that time, the one of great wisdom, MahÄkÄtyÄyana, addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If a person has the notion of Dharma and the notion of non-Dharma, relying on these two notions to expound the Dharma, this person is said to abide in ignorance.
Why is it so?
If a person sees non-Dharma as it truly is, this is the true Dharma.
World-Honored One!
If a bodhisattva sees non-Dharma as it truly is, this is the true thusness.
World-Honored One!
The true Dharma does not come from anywhere, nor does it go anywhere. The Dharma does not depend on people.
World-Honored One!
The Dharma is neither far nor near to people, and the Dharma has no distance or proximity in terms of location.
World-Honored One!
The Dharma does not think like this:
'I practice for superior beings but not for inferior or middling beings, or I practice for inferior or middling beings but not for superior beings.'
World-Honored One!
The Dharma is not named by characteristics, nor is it named by non-characteristics.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
The sage sees that all characteristics are bondage, and even the absence of characteristics is also bondage.
World-Honored One!
The Dharma is neither apart from nor cultivated.
World-Honored One!
Those who understand the Dharma are far removed from separation and cultivation.
World-Honored One!
The Dharma is neither given to others nor taken by oneself, yet it benefits according to one's wishes, because there is no doer.
World-Honored One!
The Dharma does not give rise to the thought of intimacy towards the Buddhas, nor does it arouse the thought of enmity towards ordinary beings. World-Honored One!
Because there are no thoughts of discrimination and argument.
World-Honored One!
The Dharma is neither close to the Buddhas nor far from ordinary beings, yet the Dharma attained according to one's practice is not the same.
World-Honored One!
Such a Dharma is called the Dharma-collection.
World-Honored One!
Is the Dharma-collection I have explained in accord with the Dharma-collection spoken by the TathÄgata?
The Buddha said:
MahÄkÄtyÄyana!
What you have said accords with the Buddha's intention.
At that time, the venerable MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If a person seeks tranquility while expounding the Dharma-collection, such a person has no Dharma-collection.
World-Honored One!
All dharmas are not apart from tranquility, because they are non-dual.
As for dualistic dharmas, they do not know duality, because they are far removed from the cognition of mind, thought, and consciousness;
As for singular dharmas, they also do not seek duality, because they are far removed from the desire to seek dharmas;
As for singular dharmas, they are also not two, because they are without any fabrication.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
As for tranquility, it is the non-dual Dharma;
As for the non-dual Dharma, it is not apart from all dharmas.
World-Honored One!

All dharmas are non-dual in their characteristics, because they are empty of inherent nature. Their inherent nature is without characteristics, without aspirations, without activities, unborn, unceasing, not a pure characteristic, yet can be attained, not an impure characteristic, yet can be attained. It is not attained by the stingy, nor by the generous, not attained by the one with broken precepts, nor by the one with precepts, not attained by the angry, nor by the patient, not attained by the lazy, nor by the diligent, not attained by the distracted, nor by the one in meditation, not attained by the ignorant, nor by the wise.
If one can thus not attain all dharmas, this is called truly attaining the Dharma.

If one attains something in the dharmas, then one is unable to attain; if one has a realm of activity, then one is unable to attain. The mind's realm of activity, one who practices the two dharmas, one who sees the existing dharmas, one who relies on the dharmas, one who seeks to realize the dharmas, one who is free from afflictions, one who seeks the ultimate, one who sees the Buddha, one who sees the Dharma and Saá¹ƒgha, one who sees the world, one who sees nirvÄá¹‡a, then one is unable to attain such a realm.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
If a person seeks the Dharma, then with regard to all dharmas one should have nothing to seek.
World-Honored One!
Not seeking anything in all dharmas is called truly seeking the Dharma.
World-Honored One!
The bodhisattva of right view does not see dharmas or non-dharmas, but contemplates the dharmas thus:
'Being far removed from the mind of mine and having nothing to which it clings is called the true Dharma;
If one is far removed from falsehood and unreality, that is called the true Dharma;'
If one is able to be far removed from all seeking, this is called the true Dharma;
If one understands that all dharmas are free from conceptual proliferation, this is called the true Dharma.
If there are bodhisattvas who are able to speak in this way, this is called the true Dharma collection.
World-Honored One!
Is what I have now spoken of as the marvelous Dharma collection in accord with the TathÄgata's Dharma collection?
The Buddha said:
KÄÅ›yapa!
What you have spoken accords with the Buddha's intention.
At that time, the Venerable SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
That which is called the Dharma is called non-disputation.
If one is able to be without disputation, this person has the Dharma.
World-Honored One!
The eye and form are without disputation;
The ear and sound, the nose and smell, the tongue and taste, the body and touch, the mind and dharmas are also without disputation, this is called the Dharma.
Moreover, how are the two dharmas of the eye and form without disputation?
Because they are not in union, and because these two dharmas do not reach each other.
Ear and sound, nose and smell, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and dharmas are also not in union and do not reach each other.
That which does not reach and does not unite with dharmas is all without conflict.
World-Honored One!
Dharmas are non-dual, therefore dharmas do not argue.
World-Honored One!

All dharmas are non-dual, each not knowing the other, not knowing, not discriminating, apart from various discriminations, unborn, unceasing, neither increasing nor decreasing, neither delighted nor disgusted, not abiding in the world, not abiding in nirvÄá¹‡a.
As for true dharmas, they do not say that a person can attain dharmas, or that dharmas are attained by a person.
World-Honored One!
All dharmas are neither disgusted nor delighted, neither defiled nor pure.
World-Honored One!
If a person says, 'I know, I realize, I speak,' such words are all false discriminations of the twelve sense bases.
World-Honored One!
These sense-bases do not have such a mind, thinking:
'I can discriminate.'
If a person can understand such dharmas, one should know that this person does not dispute with things;
if one can not dispute with things, this person accords with the Dharma of the Åšramaá¹‡a;

if one can accord with the practice of the Åšramaá¹‡a, this person does not go or come, does not move or stay, does not advance or retreat, sees the Dharma as the practice of the Dharma, sees the Dharma as the practice of liberation, sees the Dharma as the Dharma realm, sees the Dharma as the ultimate, but does not see any ultimate one.
All the dharmas seen are only names, only empty and false, only illusory. If one can see in this way that the empty and false is not real, such people are called those who see the Dharma.
World-Honored One!

Seeing the Dharma is called seeing the Buddha, seeing non-Dharma is called seeing the Buddha, seeing the Buddha is called seeing all sentient beings, seeing non-sentient beings is called seeing causes and conditions, seeing non-causes and conditions is called seeing emptiness, seeing non-emptiness is called not seeing.
World-Honored One!
This is called the correct view of all dharmas.
World-Honored One!
If one can correctly view all dharmas in this way, one should know that such a person is able to follow the Buddha's intention, accord with the Dharma, and accord with the Sangha.
World-Honored One!

If bodhisattvas attain such forbearance in the Dharma of non-disputation, they will not even dispute with those mÄras, let alone give rise to disputes with fellow bodhisattvas who practice the same path.
It is impossible for them to dispute.
Why is it so?
Because these bodhisattvas see all speech as able to accomplish their practice, therefore they should not dispute with others.
Because of being without dispute, bodhisattvas ultimately attain the Dharma of non-disputation.
Because they have attained the Dharma of non-disputation, these bodhisattvas are said to have attained all ultimate dharmas and attained equality in all dharmas.
Just as they see their own self as equal, they see all dharmas in the same way, abiding in equality and accepting equality. Therefore, they are said to have attained the ultimate.
All dharmas are equal, without going and without coming. Therefore, they are said to have attained the ultimate.
World-Honored One!

If bodhisattvas attain the ultimate of all dharmas in this way, then all the words and teachings of these bodhisattvas are the collection of the Dharma, bringing peace and happiness to all sentient beings.

SubhÅ«ti!

When you now expound this Dharma collection, five thousand devas become free from defilements and attain the pure Dharma eye with regard to dharmas, and five thousand devas generate the intention to achieve unsurpassable and perfect enlightenment.

If there are bodhisattvas who hear you expound this subtle Dharma collection, those bodhisattvas will know that their own bodies have reached the great Dharma ocean, and they will know that this body is not in vain, and will certainly attain wondrous bliss.

At that time, the venerable Ä€nanda addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
All dharmas and written words are called the Dharma collection.
Why is it so?
The nature of written words has no characteristic of exhaustion, and that which has no characteristic of exhaustion is precisely written words.
World-Honored One!
I say that language is only written words.
World-Honored One!
Written words do not come out from one's own body, nor do they come out from another's body.
These names do not think:
'We emit sounds.'
World-Honored One!
The various written characters do not increase or decrease.
World-Honored One!
The bodhisattva knows that the various written characters and all dharmas have the same nature.
World-Honored One!

If the bodhisattva can thus ultimately know the sounds of all dharmas, then the bodhisattva will not be obstructed by sounds. All the sounds he hears are the sounds of the Buddha, the sounds of emptiness, the sounds of signlessness, the sounds of wishlessness, the sounds of the dharma realm, and the sounds of reality.
This bodhisattva has no single dharma that can obstruct omniscience. This bodhisattva does not see any dharma that is apart from Buddha-bodhi.
This bodhisattva sees all dharmas as completely unobstructed, and is able to see all dharmas as the same as Buddha-bodhi, without contradiction.
This bodhisattva does not see any dharmas as advancing or retreating. This bodhisattva does not see any dharmas, yet always benefits all sentient beings.
The bodhisattva thus attains the ultimate forbearance regarding all dharmas. Because of attaining this forbearance, he accomplishes the profound and delightful eloquence.
What is the profound and delightful eloquence?

This bodhisattva attains the delightful eloquence of peace and comfort - the eloquence of peace and comfort means that through eloquence, he can cause all sentient beings to attain peace and comfort.

He attains the eloquence of appropriate speech - the eloquence of appropriate speech means that according to the Dharma that sentient beings should hear, he expounds the Dharma in detail or briefly in accordance with their faculties. This is called the eloquence of appropriate speech.
He also attains the swift eloquence - the swift eloquence means that through eloquence, he swiftly teaches and transforms all sentient beings.

Moreover, one attains sharp and quick eloquence. As for sharp and quick eloquence, one expounds the Dharma according to the superior faculties and sharp wisdom of sentient beings, enabling them to attain liberation quickly and easily.

Moreover, one attains the eloquence of speaking joyfully together with the superior ones. As for the eloquence of speaking joyfully together with the superior ones, all the Dharma that is expounded is the same as that of the Buddha.

Moreover, one increases eloquence. As for increasing eloquence, according to the eloquence, one is able to give rise to hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of superior and superior eloquence by expounding a single letter or phrase.
One attains the eloquence of speaking lightly and joyfully.
What is the eloquence of speaking lightly and joyfully?
According to the various kinds of eloquence, one knows the characteristics and expounds the Dharma.
Moreover, one attains the eloquence of delight. As for the eloquence of delight, according to the eloquence, one causes those who hear the Dharma to be insatiable.
Moreover, one attains the eloquence of being well-disciplined. As for the eloquence of being well-disciplined, all the eloquence does not go against the Buddha's intention.
Moreover, one attains soft and gentle eloquence - soft and gentle eloquence means that all eloquence is free from arrogance and carelessness.
Moreover, one attains tranquil eloquence - tranquil eloquence means that according to one's eloquence, one can cause oneself and others to be tranquil.

Moreover, one attains eloquence that accords with sounds - eloquence that accords with sounds means that according to one's eloquence, one teaches and transforms sentient beings to enter the Å›rÄvaka vehicle.

Moreover, one attains eloquence that is far removed - eloquence that is far removed means that according to one's eloquence, one teaches and transforms sentient beings to attain the pratyekabuddha vehicle.

Moreover, one attains unequaled eloquence - unequaled eloquence means that according to one's eloquence, one can speak of the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha.
Moreover, one attains the eloquence of tranquility - the eloquence of tranquility means that according to one's eloquence, one is able to expound all the factors of enlightenment.
Moreover, one attains the eloquence free from reproach - the eloquence free from reproach means that according to one's eloquence, one causes sentient beings to rejoice and have faith.
Moreover, one attains the eloquence of the various powers - the eloquence of the various powers means that according to one's eloquence, one is able to subdue all mÄras and non-Buddhist doctrines.

Moreover, one attains the eloquence of skillful explanation - the eloquence of skillful explanation means that with one's eloquence, one expounds the Dharma for the four assemblies without giving rise to fear.
World-Honored One!
Such is called the collection of wondrous Dharma.
World-Honored One!
Do I now attain accord with the TathÄgata's teachings in expounding the Dharma collection?
The Buddha said:
Aniruddha!

At that time, the Venerable RÄhula addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas who wish to expound the Dharma should seek out those who uphold the Dharma.
Why is this?
Because the Dharma is obtained from those who uphold it, therefore one should seek it.
Only seeking the Dharma with a focused mind is the best.
Why is this?
Because the Dharma can be obtained through valuing the Dharma, not through valuing food to obtain the benefits of the true Dharma;
Knowing that abandoning one's body and life will certainly have future results, not obtaining retribution for what is observed;
Always seeking a quiet place, not delighting in confusion, being close to those who are at peace, not to those who violate precepts;
Being close to those who are respectful, not to those who are arrogant, being close to those who practice happily, not to those who are harsh;
Being close to those with a gentle mind, not to those who are obstinate, being close to those with a tranquil mind, not to those who are attached;
Being close to those who confess their faults, not to those who conceal their evil, being close to those who delight in giving everything;
Not to those who are stingy and jealous, being close to those who uphold precepts, not to those who violate precepts, being close to those who practice patience;
those who are not hateful, those who are close to diligence and not lazy, those who are close to meditation and not distracted,

those who are close to wisdom and not foolish, those who are close to the learned and not the unlearned, those who are close to right mindfulness and not wrong mindfulness, those who are close to cultivating good deeds and not evil deeds,
those who are close to those who delight in the Buddha's teachings and not those who delight in worldly teachings,
those who are close to those who delight in emptiness and not those who fall into wrong views, those who are close to those who uphold the precepts and not those who take refuge in themselves.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
If a person is able to uphold the precepts, that person will have the Dharma.
What are the precepts?
World-Honored One!
All precepts are included within the three kinds of precepts.
What are the three?
They are the superior precepts, superior concentration, and superior wisdom.
World-Honored One!
If a bodhisattva can study in these three kinds of precepts, one should know that this person has already studied in all the precepts of the Great Vehicle.
World-Honored One!
What is the superior morality of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas are able to uphold the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts, but do not take the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts as pure, because they rely on cultivating and upholding the bodhisattva precepts;

Up to small offenses, they are fearful in their minds, because they rely on the wisdom of the bodhisattvas.
What is the wisdom of bodhisattvas?
It means that bodhisattvas know all dharmas as they really are, and because they are not afraid of karmic afflictions, this is called the wisdom of bodhisattvas.
What is the realm of bodhisattvas?
It is said to be emptiness, not the realm of various discriminations.
Knowing the equality of precepts and learning precepts, knowing the equality of emptiness and learning precepts, therefore it is said to know the equality of emptiness and learn precepts.

Knowing the equality of signlessness, knowing the equality of wishlessness, knowing the equality of non-practice, knowing the equality of non-arising and non-cessation and learning precepts, therefore it is said to know equality and learn precepts.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
The bodhisattva thinks like this:
I will now cause all sentient beings to uphold this prÄtimoká¹£a precept.
This is called the bodhisattva's superior training in precepts.
World-Honored One!
What is the bodhisattva's superior training in concentration?

The bodhisattva also thinks like this:
I will now accomplish all sentient beings with this superior training in concentration.
This is called the bodhisattva's superior training in concentration.
What is the bodhisattva's superior training in wisdom?
Namely, the bodhisattva studies the eighteen kinds of emptiness.
The bodhisattva further thinks like this:
'I now use these eighteen kinds of empty dharmas to cause all sentient beings to know and see them.'
This is called the bodhisattva's superior wisdom learning.
World-Honored One!
The three kinds of learning of the bodhisattva can all include all learnings.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
If there is a bodhisattva who can protect sentient beings, such a bodhisattva can uphold pure precepts;
If one upholds pure precepts but does not become attached to upholding precepts, such a bodhisattva, relying on upholding precepts, fulfills the minds of all sentient beings.

The bodhisattva who has left the household and upholds precepts does not give rise to attachment to any objects;ğŸ”½The bodhisattva who upholds precepts in tranquility does not give rise to a joyful mind towards any words;ğŸ”½The bodhisattva who upholds precepts while sitting in meditation does not give rise to a joyful mind towards any sounds that are spoken;
The bodhisattva who upholds precepts through dhyÄna concentration does not give rise to a joyful mind towards any sense objects;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of liberation does not give rise to a joyful mind towards any place of birth;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of hearing the Dharma does not give rise to a joyful mind towards worldly teachings;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of expounding the Dharma does not become weary even if he goes to hundreds of thousands of myriads of millions of yojanas to expound the Dharma;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of protecting the Dharma does not become weary in the midst of all afflictions, harm, and oppressive matters;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of the mind of enlightenment cultivates all practices solely for the sake of bringing happiness to all sentient beings, not for his own sake;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of the profound mind wishes to cause all sentient beings to first attain enlightenment, not seeking to realize it himself;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of the superior profound mind gives rise to much joy in benefiting others, not giving rise to a joyful mind in benefiting himself;
The bodhisattva who upholds the precepts of practice diligently cultivates for the sake of each factor of enlightenment for immeasurable eons, able to accomplish those factors without becoming weary;
Bodhisattvas who practice giving and upholding precepts are able to give up their heads, eyes, marrow, and brain to benefit sentient beings;
Bodhisattvas who practice precepts of pure conduct do not abandon sentient beings who violate precepts;
Bodhisattvas who practice precepts of forbearance and patience are not afraid of any demons' disturbances;
Bodhisattvas who practice precepts of diligent practice cultivate bodhi for the sake of all sentient beings without becoming weary;
Bodhisattvas who practice precepts of meditative concentration do not become attached to any sounds or activities;
Bodhisattvas who practice precepts of prajÃ±Ä see the nature of all dharmas as equal to the characteristics of bodhi;
Bodhisattvas who practice precepts of emptiness do not engage in worldly conduct;
Bodhisattvas who practice precepts of great compassion do not enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
World-Honored One!
Such upholding of precepts is called the Dharma assembly.
World-Honored One!
Do the Dharma assemblies I have now spoken accord with what the TathÄgata has said?
The Buddha said:
RÄhula!
What you have said accords with the Buddha's intention.
At that time, the venerable UpÄli addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

If a bodhisattva himself is far removed from afflictions and also causes sentient beings to be far removed from afflictions, he will exhaust the realms of sentient beings, dharmas, and greed, anger, and delusion.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:
'Until the realms of sentient beings, dharmas, and greed, anger, and delusion are exhausted, I will teach and transform sentient beings for that long without becoming weary.'
The bodhisattva further thinks like this:
'All dharmas are originally quiescent and extinguished, yet sentient beings are unaware and do not realize it.'
Why is it so?ğŸ”½In the emptiness and quiescence of all dharmas, there is no activity - that is to say, all wrong views and disputes are completely inactive;
In the extinction of the signlessness of all dharmas, all conceptual thoughts, reflections, and equal minds are completely inactive;
All dharmas are extinguished without aspiration, in that place all sought after and desired dharmas do not operate at all;

All dharmas are extinguished without self, in that place all attachments do not operate at all;ğŸ”½All dharmas are extinguished without sentient beings, in that place all kinds of things do not operate at all;
All dharmas are extinguished without life, in that place all birth and death do not operate at all;
All dharmas are extinguished in the true reality, in that place all falsehoods do not operate at all;

All dharmas are extinguished in the gathering of causes and conditions, in that place all life does not operate at all;ğŸ”½All dharmas are extinguished in the four establishments of mindfulness, in that place all mindfulness and practices do not operate at all;ğŸ”½All dharmas are extinguished in the four right efforts, in that place all dharmas are neither grasped nor abandoned and do not operate;
All dharmas are extinguished in the four bases of supernatural power, in that place there is neither going nor coming and they do not operate;
All dharmas are extinguished in the five faculties, and there all high and low do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in the five powers, and there all subjugation does not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in the seven factors of enlightenment, and there all dark appearances do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in the eightfold noble path, and there all evil karma and wrong thoughts do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in the ten powers, and there all habitual tendencies do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in the four fearlessnesses, and there all fear and dread do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, and there all deliberate activities do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in wisdom, and there all ignorance does not function;

All dharmas are extinguished in the absence of a creator, and there all activities do not function;ğŸ”½All dharmas are extinguished in the absence of thought, and there all cognition does not function;
All dharmas are extinguished in the absence of perception, and there all name-and-form do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished without reliance, in that place all six sense bases do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished without exhaustion, in that place all contacts do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished without cognition, in that place all feelings do not function;
All dharmas are extinguished without self, in that place all craving does not function;
All dharmas are extinguished without anything to grasp, in that place all grasping does not function;
All dharmas are extinguished without a body, in that place all existence does not function;
All dharmas are not extinguished, in that place all birth does not function;
All dharmas are extinguished with solidity, in that place all aging does not function;
All dharmas are extinguished without exhaustion, in that place all death does not function.
World-Honored One!
This is called the unobstructed wisdom gate of all bodhisattvas.

Bodhisattvas dwelling in this unobstructed wisdom gate cannot be subdued by any demons, cannot be destroyed by non-Buddhist teachers, know that all afflictions cannot defile them, are always praised by all buddhas, and are revered by all devas.
World-Honored One!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who can reach such an ultimate wisdom gate are called those who have attained the great treasury of the Dharma, are called those who are not poor, are called those who guard the secret treasury of all buddhas and tathÄgatas, are called those who are trusted by all buddhas and tathÄgatas, are called those who have done what should be done and accomplished what should be accomplished, are called those who have attained their own benefit, just as the great ocean cannot be measured and Mount Sumeru cannot be shaken.
World-Honored One!
This is called the supreme and wonderful Dharma collection.
World-Honored One!
Do I now speak the Dharma collection in accordance with what the TathÄgata has said?
The Buddha said:
UpÄli!
What you have said now accords with the Buddha's intention.
UpÄli!
Those bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who rely on this Dharma-collection to practice will be able to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
At that time, the venerable Ä€nanda addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The bodhisattvas' protection and upholding of the wonderful Dharma is the most distinguished among all practices.
World-Honored One!
If bodhisattvas are able to practice the protection and upholding of the wonderful Dharma, they will accord with enlightenment and all Buddha-TathÄgatas.
Why is this?
Because all Buddha-TathÄgatas revere the Dharma.
World-Honored One!
What is meant by protecting and upholding the wonderful Dharma?

It means that bodhisattvas are able to expound all the Buddhas' profound sÅ«tras, read them, recite them, contemplate them, and cultivate them. This is called the bodhisattvas' protection and upholding of the wonderful Dharma.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
If bodhisattvas embrace and practice, it is called the protection and upholding of the wonderful Dharma.
World-Honored One!
What is the bodhisattvas' practice of embracing?
World-Honored One!

All the bodhisattvas' physical, verbal, and mental actions are for the benefit of all sentient beings. Great compassion is foremost, and with the superior power of great kindness, they protect sentient beings and enable them to attain peace and happiness.
The bodhisattvas who protect the Dharma think like this with such a profound mind:
'Whatever practices can bring peace and happiness to sentient beings, I should practice such practices.'
Therefore, they accomplish the contemplation within the five aggregates. Although they contemplate in this way, they do not seek to abandon the five aggregates.
Contemplating the realms as poisonous snakes, they cultivate the practices, but their minds do not seek to abandon the eighteen realms;
Contemplating the sense bases as empty villages, they cultivate the practices, but their minds do not seek to abandon the twelve sense bases;
In this way, they contemplate form as foam and cultivate the practices, but their minds do not abandon the accomplishment of the adornments of the form body of the buddhas and tathÄgatas;

Contemplating feelings as like bubbles in cultivating practice, yet not abandoning the mind to accomplish the dhyÄna concentrations, samÄdhis, and samÄpattis of the buddhas and tathÄgatas, and the buddhas' wondrous bliss;
Contemplating perceptions as like mirages in cultivating practice, yet not abandoning the mind to accomplish the buddhas' and tathÄgatas' wisdom and practice;
Contemplating mental formations as like plantain trees in cultivating practice, yet not abandoning the mind to accomplish the buddhas' and tathÄgatas' wondrous Dharma practice;
Contemplating consciousness as like an illusion in cultivating practice, yet not abandoning the mind to accomplish wisdom as foremost, and the pure practice of physical, verbal, and mental actions.

Practicing giving without seeking rewards, practicing precepts to save those who violate precepts, practicing patience to subdue sentient beings, practicing vigor to accomplish all wholesome dharmas, practicing meditation to attain mental and physical pliancy, practicing wisdom to illuminate all dharma characteristics, practicing the four establishments of mindfulness to have no mental and physical defilements, practicing the four right efforts to attain unobstructed wisdom, practicing the five faculties to be able to accomplish progressive practices, practicing the five powers to not regress from enlightenment, practicing the seven factors of awakening to be free from doubts and webs, practicing the eightfold noble path to be free from faults, practicing the four kinds of pure conduct to attain mental freedom and mastery.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
If a bodhisattva knows emptiness, then he will be able to embrace the wonderful Dharma.
Moreover, emptiness is called the absence of conceptual proliferation.
World-Honored One!
Those who have conceptual proliferation have no embracing of the wonderful Dharma.
World-Honored One!
If one knows emptiness and signlessness, then one is said to embrace the sublime Dharma;
If one grasps at signs, then one does not embrace the sublime Dharma.
World-Honored One!
Because all dharmas are empty and signless, there is no aspiration. One who has no aspiration is able to embrace the sublime Dharma;
One who relies on aspiration has no embracing of the sublime Dharma.
World-Honored One!

One who sees all dharmas has no embracing of the sublime Dharma. One who relies on self and what belongs to self has no embracing of the sublime Dharma. One who is arrogant has no embracing of the sublime Dharma. One who relies on offerings, respect, and praise has no embracing of the sublime Dharma. One who relies on jealousy and stinginess has no embracing of the sublime Dharma. One who is attached to desire and harbors ill-will has no embracing of the sublime Dharma.
World-Honored One!

One who embraces the sublime Dharma, because the bodhisattva does not give rise to the notion of distinction regarding sentient beings and does not give rise to the notion of distinction regarding dharmas.
World-Honored One!
In this way, bodhisattvas embrace the sublime Dharma.
World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas see that all dharmas are unborn and unceasing, this is called bodhisattvas embracing the sublime Dharma;
Bodhisattvas see that all sentient beings do not go or come, this is called bodhisattvas embracing the sublime Dharma;
Seeing one's own body is neither defiled nor pure, this is called bodhisattvas embracing the sublime Dharma;
Not delighting in the Buddha Dharma and not despising the non-Buddhist paths, this is called bodhisattvas embracing the sublime Dharma;
Upholding the eighty-four thousand dharma treasuries without giving rise to the notion of dharma characteristics, this is called bodhisattvas embracing the sublime Dharma;

Not sharing in all afflictions, secondary afflictions, and abiding in all evil and unwholesome dharmas without giving rise to the notion of non-dharma, this is called bodhisattvas embracing the sublime Dharma;
Attaining the liberated mind without giving rise to the thought:
'I have attained liberation.'
This is called bodhisattvas embracing the sublime Dharma;
To perform the duties of a disciple to all buddhas, yet not to give rise to thoughts of body, speech, or mind in practicing, is called the bodhisattva's embracing of the sublime Dharma;
To be sovereign over all dharmas, yet not to give rise to thoughts of dharma or non-dharma, is called the bodhisattva's embracing of the sublime Dharma;
To practice without grasping or rejecting any dharmas, is called the bodhisattva's embracing of the sublime Dharma;
To practice without seeking to attain the Dharma or realize it, is called the bodhisattva's embracing of the sublime Dharma;
To not give rise to an attached mind towards any objects, is called the bodhisattva's embracing of the sublime Dharma;

If a bodhisattva gives rise to a mind that is neither that of an ordinary person, nor that of a learner, nor that of an arhat, and cuts off the bonds of greed, anger, and delusion without relying on anything, this is called the bodhisattva's embracing of the sublime Dharma;
If a bodhisattva receives a prediction of enlightenment but does not seek buddha-enlightenment, this is called the bodhisattva's embracing of the sublime Dharma;
If a bodhisattva, when approaching the site of enlightenment, sees the site of enlightenment everywhere, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can subdue the mÄras without seeing the mÄras and their retinue, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can accomplish the enlightenment of buddhahood without realizing the previously non-existent Dharma, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can turn the great Dharma wheel without creating sentient beings and without destroying sentient beings, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can subdue the mÄras and non-Buddhist paths without quarreling, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can be born without being newly born and without being born from before, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can die without being exhausted, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can transcend the three realms without going anywhere, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the wonderful Dharma;
If one can transcend all language and sound without language, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the sublime Dharma;
If one can be neither greedy for nor averse to any dharma, this is called the bodhisattva's acceptance of the sublime Dharma.
World-Honored One!
This is called the sublime Dharma-collection.
World-Honored One!
Does what I have now explained about the Dharma-collection accord with the World-Honored One's explanation of the Dharma-collection?
The Buddha said:
Ä€nanda!
What you have explained about the Dharma-collection deeply accords with my intention.

When Ä€nanda explained this sublime Dharma-collection, 80,000 devas generated the intention to achieve unsurpassable and perfect enlightenment, 32,000 bodhisattvas attained the forbearance of the non-production of dharmas, and 500 bhiká¹£us were freed from defilements and attained liberation of the mind.
At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Maitreya addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
World-Honored One!
It is like discarding the husks and taking the rice grains.
World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas are also like this, abandoning what is contrary to the Dharma and taking up the true Dharma.

Moreover, bodhisattvas abandon stinginess and greed and take up giving, abandon breaking precepts and take up upholding precepts, abandon anger and resentment and take up patience, abandon laziness and take up diligence, abandon distraction and take up meditation, abandon foolishness and take up wisdom. This is called the supreme and wonderful Dharma collection.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
Those who seek are not in accord with the Dharma;ğŸ”½If one does not seek, then one does not take;
If one does not take, then one does not guard;ğŸ”½If one does not guard, then one is not defiled;
If one is not defiled, then one does not dispute;ğŸ”½If one does not dispute, then one is not stingy;ğŸ”½If one is not stingy, then one does not harm;
If one does not harm, then one does not act;
If one does not act, then one does not regress;
If a bodhisattva is irreversible, the buddhas and tathÄgatas will give them the prediction of unsurpassed and perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
This is called the Dharma, this is called the sublime Dharma-collection.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
If a bodhisattva gives rise to this thought:
'I am irreversible from the mind of unsurpassed and perfect enlightenment,'
the buddhas and tathÄgatas will not give them the prediction.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
All afflictions have seeking as their root.
World-Honored One!
Far from seeking is called being free from afflictions. Because of being free from afflictions, the buddhas and tathÄgatas give them the prediction.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
A bodhisattva thinks like this:
'Receiving a prediction is a false worldly verbal expression.
Why is it so?
The one who receives the prediction is nonexistent, and the one who bestows the prediction is also nonexistent. If both are nonexistent, where is the prediction received?
Yes, World-Honored One!
Great compassion accords with worldly conventions and has such speech.
If a bodhisattva can understand such dharmas, this is called a bodhisattva's prediction.
World-Honored One!
It is like an illusionist bestowing a prediction, but the illusory one has no such thought:
I receive the prediction, I attain perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
The bodhisattva is also like that, without a discriminating mind like the illusory one.
But the bodhisattva thinks like this:
Enlightenment is not a characteristic that can be realized, nor is it a characteristic that can be abandoned;
Enlightenment is not a characteristic of arising, nor is it a characteristic of ceasing;
Enlightenment is not realized by the body, nor is it realized by the mind;
Enlightenment is not within, not without, and not in between;
Enlightenment has no such thought:
I am bodhi, and bodhisattvas are able to realize me.
World-Honored One!
This is called the supreme and wonderful Dharma collection.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!

Bodhisattvas on the ground of joy are neither ashamed nor distressed, on the ground of dispassion they neither increase nor decrease, on the ground of radiance they are neither dark nor bright, on the ground of blazing they neither grasp nor abandon, on the ground of difficult to conquer they have no victory or defeat, on the ground of presence they do not awaken by themselves or through others, on the ground of far-reaching they do not go or stay, on the ground of immovable they are neither moved nor discriminate, on the ground of excellent wisdom they neither accomplish nor wish to accomplish, and on the ground of Dharma clouds they neither awaken by themselves nor through others. On the ground of buddhahood, they are able to perform all activities yet do not perform any activities.
Therefore, the TathÄgata is naturally free from conceptual proliferation.
World-Honored One!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's excellent and wonderful Dharma collection.
World-Honored One!
The bodhisattva thus attains the wisdom of accord and is able to freely expound the Dharma.
What is meant by freedom in expounding the Dharma?
It is because one is not attached to any language.
Moreover, one attains the freedom of purity.
What is meant by the freedom of purity?
It is because one is unstained by anything.
Moreover, one attains the freedom of eloquent expression.
What is meant by the freedom of eloquent expression?
It is because one can expound the Dharma without interruption for hundreds of thousands of myriads of eons based on a single principle or phrase.
Moreover, one attains the freedom of wisdom.
What is meant by the freedom of wisdom?
It is because one can expound hundreds of thousands of myriads of Dharma gates based on a single principle or phrase.
Moreover, one attains the freedom of birth.
What is meant by the freedom of birth?
It is because one is born in whatever place one can benefit sentient beings.
Moreover, one attains the freedom of samÄdhi.
What is meant by the freedom of samÄdhi?
Because in every thought, if one wishes to enter samÄdhi, one is able to enter samÄdhi.
Moreover, one attains mastery over abiding.
What is mastery over abiding?
Because one is able to expound the wondrous Dharma of the buddhas by abiding and empowering whatever one abides in, whether it be a hare, a bird, a beast, grass, trees, or stone walls.
Moreover, one attains mastery over retinue.
What is mastery over retinue?
Because one attains immeasurable retinue and indestructible retinue.
Moreover, one attains mastery over seeing.
What is mastery over seeing?
It means seeing wondrous forms.
Moreover, one attains mastery over hearing.
What is mastery over hearing?
It means hearing wondrous sounds.
Moreover, one attains mastery over the nose.
What is mastery over the nose?
Because all smells one encounters are only the fragrance of the wondrous Dharma.
Moreover, one attains mastery over the tongue.
What is mastery over the tongue?
It means consuming the flavor of the Dharma and not consuming the flavor of food.
Moreover, one attains mastery over the body.
What is mastery over the body?
It is because one attains the accomplishment of the Dharma body, not the body sustained by food.
Moreover, one attains mastery over the mind.
What is mastery over the mind?
It is because one knows the activities and minds of mosquitoes, gadflies, and ants.
World-Honored One!
This is called the supreme and wonderful Dharma collection.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Seen and Loved by All said to the Buddha, World-Honored One!
World-Honored One!
When bodhisattvas practice like this, when sentient beings see them practicing like this, they immediately give rise to joy.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas do nothing else but teach and transform sentient beings.
World-Honored One!
This is called the fundamental supreme and wonderful Dharma collection of bodhisattvas.
World-Honored One!
Therefore, bodhisattvas should cultivate and study the practice of delighting in the Dharma.
World-Honored One!
What is delighting in the Dharma?
Bodhisattvas have four kinds of delight in the Dharma.
What are the four?

Namely, giving to all sentient beings without seeking rewards, the mind of equality, protecting all sentient beings' evil conduct with loving speech, accomplishing benefits, and loving all sentient beings as one's own self with the same purpose.
World-Honored One!
This is called the four kinds of joyful dharmas of bodhisattvas, which are loved by all sentient beings.
Furthermore, there are four dharmas that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas can use to create joyful events.
What are the four?
Namely, wisdom from much learning, because of an unarrogant mind;
forgetting appearances in expounding the Dharma, because of being free from the thought of offerings;
giving rise to respect for those venerable ones, because of seeking wisdom;
engaging in vigorous effort, because of teaching and transforming all sentient beings. These are called the four dharmas that bodhisattvas can use to create joyful events.
Furthermore, there are four dharmas that bodhisattvas can use to create joyful events.
What are the four?
Namely, accomplishing pure precepts, because of giving the Dharma as gifts;ğŸ”½Accomplishing contentment, because of abiding in a tranquil place;
Because of abiding in a secluded place, one attains meditation;
Dwelling well in cities and villages, because of not breaking the boundaries of deportment.
These are called the four dharmas of bodhisattvas that can create delightful things.
There are four more dharmas, namely:

Truthful speech, because of eloquent speech; Dharma speech, because of speaking of emptiness; patient speech, because of an impartial mind; and tranquil speech, because of guarding the senses. These are called the four dharmas of bodhisattvas that can create delightful things.
Furthermore, bodhisattvas have four dharmas that can create delightful things.
What are the four?
Namely, first inquiring with a good intention, because of kind words;
An easy-to-fill mind, because of knowing contentment with little;
Accomplishing non-deviousness, because of speaking and acting in accordance with one's words;
The thicket of deceit and fraud, because they do not deceive any sentient beings.
These are called the four dharmas that bodhisattvas are able to do as delightful things.
Furthermore, there are four dharmas that bodhisattvas are able to do as delightful things.
What are the four?
Namely, not giving rise to an evil mind, because of inner tranquility;
Not giving rise to a deluded mind, because of non-invertedness externally;
Not giving rise to a stingy mind, because of contemplating that all things are impermanent;
Not giving rise to a mind of arrogance, because of knowing all dharmas as they really are.
These are called the four dharmas that bodhisattvas are able to do as delightful things.
Furthermore, there are four dharmas that bodhisattvas are able to do as delightful things.
What are the four?
Namely, attaining a profound mind, because of first wishing to inquire;
Being far removed from attachment, because of attaining gentle and affectionate speech;
Abandoning all minds while always not abandoning the bodhi mind;
The ultimate truth is foremost, yet they accord with worldly truth.
These are called the four dharmas that bodhisattvas are able to do for the sake of what is delightful.
World-Honored One!
This is called the sublime Dharma assembly.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas attain the foremost emptiness, attain great unobstructed understanding, attain great mastery, and skillfully know how to speak
about the Dharma assembly. They delight in the profound Dharma and accord with all beings. Ultimately they attain
the inconceivable and rare Dharma. Those who attain the gentle and soft Dharma attain the great unobstructed understanding.
Those who attain the great Dharma master attain the great Dharma king. Those who attain the great creator create the great
assembly of beings to rely on. Those who attain the great unobstructed mastery, in order to teach and transform beings, do not regress,
and although born, are not born. Although they die, they do not die. What they have accomplished is accomplished and they attain enlightenment.
They attain the liberated mind and give rise to diligence. They enter nirvana and practice fulfillment, and seek
seeking, and practicing all-knowledge, and asking others.
World-Honored One!
All oceans can be measured, but the great vehicle wisdom ocean of those bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cannot be measured.
World-Honored One!
Space can be purified of dust, but the minds of those bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cannot be defiled.
World-Honored One!
Although the wind has no form, it can be grasped with the hand, but the minds of those bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are not attached to the six sense objects.
World-Honored One!
The heat of spring can be grasped, but the mind of those bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas that grasps 'I' and 'mine' cannot be obtained.
World-Honored One!
This is called the supreme and wonderful Dharma collection.
At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Good Eyes said to the Buddha:ğŸ”½World-Honored One!
World-Honored One!
Bodhisattvas cultivate all dharmas, only giving rise to the mind of enlightenment as the fundamental basis.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
All dharmas are false, only the mind discriminates, and the essence is devoid of all things.
Free from all things, like an illusion without a root, it becomes what is sought;
Far removed from the doer and the receiver, its nature does not abide, because it is free from all abodes.
World-Honored One!
All dharmas have no beginning and no end, because they are non-dual and free from duality.
World-Honored One!
All dharmas are without self and without what belongs to self, because they have no owner;
All dharmas are equal, like the dharma realm, because they are not guests.
World-Honored One!
All dharmas are not the master, because they are free from all craving;
All dharmas are free from discrimination and various discriminations, because they are free from the mind that can grasp and abandon;
All dharmas do not come or go, because they are only the realm of wisdom, because there is no knowing and the master is empty.
World-Honored One!

These ordinary beings at the tips of those hairs give rise to the thought of self in the Dharma of no-self, and give rise to the thought of sentient beings in the absence of sentient beings. The bodhisattva thinks like this:
'I will use such wonderful Dharma to enable sentient beings to attain understanding and realization.'
World-Honored One!

This is called the mind of enlightenment, the mind of peace and happiness for all sentient beings, the unsurpassed mind, the mind of the Dharma realm, the mind of light, and the mind of upholding sentient beings.
Giving rise to based on such a mind is called giving rise to the mind of enlightenment.
Furthermore, World-Honored One!

Practicing the perfection of giving is called the mind of tranquility; practicing the perfection of morality is called theğŸ”½mind of non-deficiency; practicing the perfection of patience is called the mind of non-harm; practicing the perfection ofğŸ”½effort is called the mind of non-retrogression; practicing the perfection of meditation is called the mind of non-disturbance;
practicing the perfection of wisdom is called the mind of non-discrimination and non-delusion; practicing the
Great compassion is called the mind of non-retrogression, practicing great joy is called the mind of insatiable, practicing great equanimity is called the mind of non-defilement,
practicing great giving is called the mind of non-stinginess, practicing loving-kindness is called the mind of non-thicket,
practicing beneficial conduct is called the mind of equality, practicing sympathetic joy is called the mind of the highest,
practicing the wisdom of emptiness is called the mind of non-discrimination, practicing the knowledge of signlessness is called the
mind of non-thought, practicing wishlessness is called the mind of non-abiding, practicing the conduct of enlightenment is called
the mind of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, practicing the conduct of progress is called the mind of mindfulness of the Buddha,
practicing the conduct of indestructibility is called the mind of mindfulness of the Dharma, practicing the mind of the Dharma realm is called the

World-Honored One!
I rely on arousing the mind of enlightenment to speak of it being inexhaustible for one eon or innumerable eons.
Thus, all bodhisattvas accumulate innumerable causes and conditions to arouse the mind of enlightenment.
Therefore, World-Honored One!
If bodhisattvas wish to seek out all wholesome dharmas, they should know and seek it within the mind of arousing the aspiration for enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
This is called the supreme Dharma assembly.
At that time, the bodhisattva SubhÅ«ti addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
World-Honored One!
The wholesome generation of all dharmas is due to the purity of the fundamental basis.
World-Honored One!
What is the fundamental basis of all dharmas?
World-Honored One!
All dharmas have emptiness as their root, because in that place there are no views;
All dharmas have signlessness as their root, because in that place there is no discursive thought;
All dharmas have wishlessness as their root, because in that place there are no afflictions of the three realms;
All dharmas have non-action as their root, because in that place there is no agent;

All dharmas have non-self as their root, because in that place one does not see the practice of self;ğŸ”½All dharmas have the absence of sentient beings as their root, because in that place one does not see the practice of sentient beings;

All dharmas have the absence of life as their root, because in that place one sees the non-practice of life;ğŸ”½All dharmas are unborn, because in that place one does not practice the view of eternalism;
All dharmas are unceasing, because in that place one does not practice the view of annihilationism;
All dharmas are insubstantial, because in that place one does not practice the view of existence;
All dharmas are equal to nirvana, because in that place one does not practice the view of separation from existence;
All dharmas are like enlightenment, because in that place one does not engage in seeing the Buddha;
All dharmas are not created, because in that place one does not engage in seeing the Dharma;
All dharmas are not combined, because in that place one does not engage in seeing the Saá¹ƒgha.
World-Honored One!
